A reminder: you can think, move, lose focus, get distracted, and fall asleep and still derive all the benefits a meditation practice can provide. Perfection is not required (nor possible).

The single most important thing you need to know about meditation is that you don't need to make any effort to stop thinking. Trying not to think is largely impossible, and a recipe for a great deal of struggle, strain and frustration.

Some typical meditation experiences:

- not being able to stay focused
- getting distracted
- thinking continuously
- feeling agitated, annoyed, bored, frustrated, angry, sad, anxious, fearful, tired, upset, sore, etc.
- getting so relaxed you fall asleep.

Whether sitting, standing or lying, take a minute or two to compare the right and left sides of the body, noting how your weight is distributed, any asymmetries, and the curvature of your spine.

But what we often get is a 'learning experience'.
If you don't take up the latter, you're unlikely to reliably find the former.

If you think continuously while meditating, that doesn't mean that you're not meditating; it just means you're meditating on your thoughts. That's a completely valid (and very common) meditative experience.

Soften your gaze
Breathe easily

In meditation, as in life, expectations are rarely useful. They only ever deliver a variation on what you expect — and blind you to the satisfaction available through what you're actually experiencing.

Meditation Tips

* Allow things to happen at their own pace
* Apply a minimum of effort
* Let go of the need to analyse
* Expect no particular outcome
Somewhat paradoxically, you may find that the most satisfying meditations are the ones in which you let go of all effort to control or manage your experience.

Meditating formally, in the 'correct' posture, for 20 or 30 minutes (or more), is not superior — nor necessarily more effective — than a simple moment of mindfulness (which allows you to respond more intelligently to a person or situation).

In meditation, what you focus on is less important than how you focus.
So how do you focus?
Simply with a sense of curiosity, acceptance and kindness.

Meditation requires complete silence.
One must sit still.
We mustn't get distracted.
We must remain fully present at all times.
No thoughts allowed. Thinking is bad.
Falling asleep is bad.
We must practice daily.

— Eric Harrison, The 5-Minute Meditator
Instead of berating your mind for wandering during meditation, you could celebrate each arising thought as a unique and miraculous phenomenon worthy of your interest and respect.

It's useful to approach meditation not as a way to reduce the amount of thinking that's going on, but rather as a means of developing a more harmonious relationship with those thoughts (in which you are less bothered / disturbed by them).

If, during meditation:

you have a million thoughts
your mind wanders, again and again
you feel totally lazy
you fall asleep

then you can be sure that you are doing it correctly.

Meditation Tip
Periodically, even during meditation, have a rest — a pause, a time-out — and simply be, letting your attention drift freely. This little technique will show you how much effort and striving has been getting in the way of experiencing the moment as it is.

We associate meditation with sitting cross-legged. But it's perfectly acceptable to meditate in other positions, including whilst lying down, or standing up, or whilst in motion. This gives you options when the idea or practice of sitting doesn't seem to be working for you.

Take refuge in meditation but do not use it to numb yourself.

— Lorin Roche.

In meditation, continually returning your attention to a point of focus each time you get distracted is just one option. Many people find meditation more relaxing, enjoyable — and useful — when they place less emphasis on always remaining focused.

When I respect my emotions, I inevitably feel better.

In order to get the most out of meditation you need to be able to focus (when required) upon all of the following: breath and body, sounds and senses, thoughts and mind states, emotions and moods.
Sometimes a short meditation break is all you need to turn a difficult day back around, or to remember that the present moment exists in the middle of the chaos around you.

It's easy to underestimate the value of micro-meditations and mindfulness practices. A formal meditation practice can seem more 'serious'. And yet, why would you engage in a formal meditation practice except in order to be able to apply the skills in your daily life?

To access a meditative state whenever you want, simply pay close attention to what you can see, hear, smell, taste or touch (feel). Or, as the cliché recommends: stop, and smell the roses. It's that simple.
